data.text: Contents
Introduction

The purpose of probation is to support new members of staff and help them become fully integrated and productive at the earliest opportunity. It is to establish a structured trial period allowing both The Trust and the member of staff to assess whether the member of staff is suitable for the role.

The Trust is committed to supporting all new staff as they induct into the organisation. We are also committed to providing the highest quality of care for our patients. To help us to do this, all new staff will have a probationary period which allows them time to settle into The Trust, learn the new job and receive the appropriate training.
Probationary periods will apply to all new entrants and re-entrants (substantive and fixed term) to The Trust.

If despite the efforts of management and the individual, it becomes apparent that the individual is not suited to the position to which they were appointed, this procedure provides the facility for either party to terminate the contract, giving appropriate notice, at any time during the probation period. It will be for The Trust to determine the appropriateness of early termination of any probationary contract.

The management of concerns during the probationary period should be carried out in accordance with the principles of performance management in accordance with this policy and will not require the use of formal Trust Performance Improvement (Capability) policy.
We will support all new staff as they aim to complete their probationary period successfully.
Scope
This policy applies to all staff employed by The Trust.

This policy does not apply to Contractors, Agency, Bank or Volunteer workers. It will not apply to Doctors or Dentists who will be subject to separate provisions as per the Department of health's Maintaining High Professional Standards document.
It does not form part of the member of staff's contract of employment but is a statement of The Trusts' current practice and may be changed from time to time.
Definitions

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Chief Executive is responsible for ensuring The Trust has a robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal, and national requirements are met.
Managers are responsible for:
Explaining to newly appointed members of staff the arrangements for the probation period;

Defining appropriate standards of attendance, performance and behaviour expected of the new member of staff at the commencement of their employment with The Trust as part of the local induction arrangements;
Ensuring that all new members of staff are aware of their duties and job requirement;
Ensuring that all new members of staff are aware of the policies and procedures applicable to their role;
Ensuring that adequate and appropriate support, supervision, training and development is provided for staff during their induction and probationary period;
Supporting staff in the achievement of the required standards of attendance, performance and behaviour;
Applying the policy consistently and in a way that is sensitive to issues of equality and diversity;
Conducting a probation review meeting with all new members of staff covered by this procedure at the intervals outlined in this document;
Ensuring appropriate confidentiality;
Seeking the advice of the Employee Relations Team where dismissal of a member of staff is contemplated;
Signing off the successful achievement of the probationary period;
Meeting regularly with the new member of staff during their probationary period to ensure that standards are being met and reviewed effectively and in a timely manner;
Ensure that formal meetings are held at 2, 4 and 6 months review periods.
Staff are responsible for:
Consistently behaving in accordance with the relevant Trust Values/staff charter and behavioural standards;
Consistently meeting the requirements of their employment contract (e.g. arriving on time, fulfilling their contracted hours and role);
Consistently performing effectively in their role;
Adherence to Trust policies and procedures applicable to their role;
Their own health, wellbeing and attendance at work;
Their own conduct as a member of staff of The Trust;
Their own learning;
Where appropriate, practising in accordance with their professional body's code of conduct performance and ethics, acknowledging that they are accountable for their own practice;
Preparing for the probationary review meetings;
Actively and positively participating in probation review meetings;
Positively working with their line manager to address any issues raised.
The Employee Relations Team is responsible for:

Providing specialist knowledge and advice of procedural issues, relevant policies and employment law matters to ensure fairness and consistency in approach, and includes the provision of confidential advice and assistance to managers on probation and performance management matters;
Attending formal meetings when serious concerns arise and/or when there is the possibility of a termination of contract;
Supporting the delivery of this policy and monitor its implementation.
Length of probationary period

The appointment of every new member of staff to a permanent post will be subject to a 6 month probationary period. If the member of staff is on a fixed term contract for less than 6 months, the probation period will be for the duration of the contract and will continue if the contract is extended.
A 6 month probationary period will also apply to any existing member of staff with less than 6 months continuous service with The Trust who is commencing a new role.
Probationary review meetings

During the probation period, staff are expected to demonstrate satisfactory attendance, performance, conduct and behaviour. The progress of staff during their probationary period must be monitored, ensuring that reasonable training
needs are met, the member of staff informed of their progress and ensuring any problems are addressed before they become serious concerns.
During the 6 month probationary period, at appropriate points, managers must hold formal review meetings as follows:
The first review by the end of the 2nd month;
The second review by the end of the 4th month.

A meeting will be held at the end of the member of staffs probationary period to determine whether the member of staff have completed their probationary review period, whether the member of staffs review period needs to be extended or whether the member of staff has failed to meet the standards expected in the role.

The probationary period must be properly planned with the line manager ensuring that the member of staff has clear guidance relating to the standards of performance and behaviour required in their role. This should include, for example:
Clear job outputs;
The standards of performance that are required in respect of job duties;
The standards that are required in respect of timekeeping and attendance;
The standards or measurements against which the member of staffs; performance will be assessed including quality and productivity;
Any agreed development activities;
A description of any relevant standards of behaviour including working relationships such as team work and interpersonal and communication skills;
Provision of regular constructive feedback.

There may be the need to hold additional informal or formal review meetings with the member of staff to review progress during the probationary period. For example, if the member of staff requires more frequent feedback on a particular area of concern. The dates of the additional review meetings should be scheduled in advance and the member of staff given reasonable notice.
Representation

Where the probation period is progressing successfully, review meetings are held between the manager and member of staff. However, where there are concerns about a member of staffs' performance that could result in formal outcomes that affect the member of staffs continued employment, staff have a right to be accompanied by a trade union representative or work place colleague at each formal stage of the procedure.

The chosen representative/companion is permitted to address in meetings but no right to answer questions on the member of staff's behalf. They will also be permitted reasonable time to confer privately with the member of staff and to ask questions on his/her behalf.

The Trusts relationship and communication is directly with its staff. On this basis it is the responsibility of the member of staff concerned to arrange for a representative or companion to be available to attend and to provide him/her with all relevant information and documentation. Only by mutual agreement will The Trusts deal directly with the representative.
Legal representation is not permitted at any stage of the policy or procedure, including the appeal following dismissal.

A member of the Employee Relations team may be in attendance at formal meetings. The Trust also reserves the right for a member of the Employee Relations team to be invited at the informal stage, in which case the member of staff also has right to representation.
Professional and Statutory Bodies

If, during the probationary period, there are concerns about a member of staff's fitness to practise, including concerns about a practitioner's health, which are serious enough to affect a practitioner's registration, The Trust will refer the matter to the relevant professional body. This referral will usually be undertaken by the appropriate professional lead.

If the concerns relate to the member of staff potentially posing a risk to a vulnerable adult or child (as defined by the Safeguarding Authority) the relevant Vulnerable Adult Protection co-ordinator or the Named Nurse Child Protection will be consulted as soon as possible for further immediate action to be agreed and undertaken.
If the concerns relate to the member of staff allegedly having committed an act of fraud in the course of their duties, the matter will be reported in line with The Trust's Counter Fraud Policy.
Satisfactory probationary period

At the end of a successful probationary period the manager should confirm the employment by informing the member of staff at the final review. This should be confirmed in writing within 7 calendar days.

Staff will be considered to have automatically passed their probationary period at 6 months (or 8 months if it has been extended) unless notified otherwise. Any capability/performance issues following the completion of the probation period would need to follow The Trust's Performance Improvement (Capability) Policy and Procedure.
Dealing with concerns about suitability

If at any stage during the probationary period a member of staff's performance is causing significant concern and considered not to be meeting the required standards, the member of staff must be informed how their performance is to improve.
Managers must contact the Employee Relations Team to discuss the issues;
Managers should draft an action plan and provide a copy to the member of staff prior to meeting them;
The member of staff must be formally invited to a probation review meeting and have the right to representation. A member of the Employee Relations team will also be in attendance;
At the meeting, evidence of performance must be discussed and objectives/ standards for achievement must be set for review and included in a written action plan;
Reasonable training, support and supervision will be agreed in order to assist in achieving an improvement;
Other reasons or mitigating circumstances which may be affecting the member of staffs' performance at work should be explored and support provided as appropriate;
The member of staff must be warned of the possibility that his/her employment may be terminated in accordance with this Policy if the required level of conduct/performance is not met;
The meeting discussion and outcome must be confirmed in writing within 7 calendar days.
Throughout the whole process, managers must ensure they maintain clear written documentation and evidence of where performance continues to fail to meet the required standard.
Extending the probationary period

In certain cases, at the final probation review meeting it may be reasonable to extend the probationary period by up to a further 2 months. For example, an extension to the period may be appropriate if the member of staff has been away from the work-place for a period of time due to leave, sick leave, or compassionate leave. It may also include circumstances where the member of staff's performance and / or behaviour is not at the required standard but the line manager believes that it can be attained within the limits of the extension period.
Only one extension will be allowed unless there are extenuating circumstances but that would need to be approved by Head of Employee Relations.
Staff taking up a new post within The Trust

Where a member of staff applies for and is appointed to a new role within The Trust, their new employment will not be subject to a probationary period. Should issues arise in relation to the performance of the individual the manager should address these concerns using The Trust's Performance Improvement (Capability) Policy and Procedure.

In the case of staff with less than 6 months continuous service with The Trust, who change role, e.g. following promotion, sideways move, long-term secondment or redeployment, the probationary period will continue to apply and the same process should be completed as that for new staff. The member of staff will be subject to a 6 month probationary review in the new post in order for the manager to determine whether they are meeting the expected standards.

For new members of staff where there is a delay in commencing duties, e.g. where overseas nurses have to undergo an induction and training programme, the probation period will start at the commencement of employment, but the probation period will re-start at the commencement of full duties to allow for a full 6 month assessment period to take place.
Annual leave during probation

As there is the possibility of early termination of employment under this policy, when considering annual leave requests, managers must have regard to granting leave in order for staff to avoid any overtaking of annual leave. Whilst The Trust would honour holidays already booked prior to commencing employment at The Trust, it is advisable that staff are only granted what they have accrued at the point of request during the probation period.
Absence during probation

Staff must demonstrate their commitment to attend work in accordance with their contract of employment. Therefore it is important that good attendance is attained in order to successfully complete the probation period.
Inability to demonstrate satisfactory attendance at work, is likely to result in termination of contract.

Where sickness occurs, this will be managed using the sickness absence management policy in order to be supportive, however, absences will be taken into account as to whether the probation period is successful or not. Any termination of contract due to sickness will be managed under this policy.
Dismissal during or at the end of the probationary period

The decision to terminate a probationary contract of employment may be made at any time within the probationary period but may only be made after a formal meeting, at which an appropriate senior manager is accompanied by a member of the Employee Relations team. The manager must have authority to dismiss the member of staff should this be required. The member of staff will be given the opportunity to be accompanied at the formal meeting by a work colleague or trade union representative. Staff will not be permitted to bring a solicitor or be represented by anyone acting in a professional legal capacity. The member of staff will be given the opportunity to give their response to the concerns raised before a decision is made.
Any member of staff that is dismissed during their probationary period will be entitled to appeal against the decision. Please refer to The Trust's Appeal policy.
Disciplinary issues

Where a member of staff becomes the subject of a disciplinary matter, and termination of contract may be an outcome, where appropriate, an investigation will be undertaken in order to determine the facts to ensure a fair process is followed.

If at any stage in the probationary period the member of staff is subject to disciplinary procedures, this will be managed under the Probation policy and a formal probation review meeting will be held as soon as possible. The member of staff will have the right to be accompanied at this meeting by a work colleague or trade union representative.

Should termination of contract be a possible outcome, the employment may be terminated by giving one weeks' notice. If the member of staff's conduct is considered gross misconduct the employment will be terminated without notice. The member of staff will receive a written outcome and advised of their right to appeal against the dismissal.
Gross incompetence

At any stage in the probationary period if the member of staff's performance is considered to be gross incompetence a formal meeting will be held as soon as possible and the employment may be terminated by giving 1 weeks' notice. Any relevant professional bodies will be notified. The member of staff will have the right to be accompanied at this meeting by a work colleague or trade union representative and Employee Relations will be in attendance.
Notice period

When the decision has been taken to terminate member of staff's contract of employment during or at the end of the probationary period, the notice period will be in line with the statutory timescales which for staff with less than one year's service is one week.

Should  the  member  of  staff  wish  to  terminate  their  employment  during  their probationary period they will be required to give written notice to The Trust with the notice period in line with their contract.
Training Requirements
In order to manage a probation period effectively managers should attend any training that is offered by The Trust and any other relevant internal courses.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

This procedure has been reviewed and approved by the Employee Relations team and Staff Side representatives across the Trust and will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available electronically on The Trusts intranets. Advice and support on the implementation of this procedure is available via the Employee Relations team.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trusts aim to design and implement services, policies and procedures that
meet the needs of our service, population and workforce, ensuring that none are
placed at a disadvantage over others.
In order to meet these requirements, an equality impact assessment is used to
assess all its policies, procedures and practices. This procedure was found to be
compliant with this assessment. (Refer to Appendix 1)
